titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Mardette Perkins Papers
titlestmt.author: by Beinecke staff

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Saturday April 27, 2019 at 03:00

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract: The papers provide insight into the personal and professional life of Mardette Perkins, American actress and poet, and consist of correspondence, drafts of writings, clippings, ephemera, computer media, and audiovisual material dating from 1942 to 1996. Perkins' acting career is represented in photographs, clippings, ephemera, and a film of her work for television commercials. The papers contain drafts of Perkins' poetry, including an unpublished manuscript for her "Collected Poems, I," and recordings of her reading poetry. The papers also shed light on Perkins' experience of psychoanalysis, detailed in her journals from 1961 to 1976.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.
Box 11 (computer disks): Restricted fragile material. Reference copies may be requested. Consult Access Services for further information.
Box 19 (audiocassettes): Use of originals is restricted. Reference copies may be requested. Consult Access Services for further information.
Box 20 (film): Restricted fragile material. Reference copies may be requested. Consult Access Services for further information.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Mardette Perkins Papers is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Mardette Perkins Papers. Yale Collection of American Literature, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: This collection received a basic level of processing, including rehousing and minimal organization. Information included in the Description of Papers note and Collection Contents section is drawn from information supplied with the collection and from an initial survey of the contents. Folder titles appearing in the contents list below are often based on those provided by the creator or previous custodian. Titles have not been verified against the contents of the folders in all cases. Otherwise, folder titles are supplied by staff during initial processing.
This finding aid may be updated periodically to account for new acquisitions to the collection and/or revisions in arrangement and description.
This collection includes materials previously identified by the following call numbers: Uncat ZA MS 558, Uncat ZA MS 627, and Uncat ZA MS 633.

bioghist.head: Mardette Perkins (1924-2002)
bioghist.p: Mardette Perkins, American actress, was born Margaret Hariot Edwards to Rev. H. Boyd Edwards, Sr. and Margaret Edwards on November 24, 1924 in Little Rock, Arkansas. She attended St. Margaret's School in Waterbury, CT., Wellesley College (1942-1946), and the Yale School of Drama (1946-1948). She married Robert Wilder Perkins on January 31, 1959 with whom she had sons Charles and Morgan. She died on May 23, 2002.

Perkins appeared in stage productions of "The Man Who Came for Dinner" (Plymouth Theater, 1949) and "Heartbreak House" (Bleeker Street Theatre, 1950). Her work for television includes "The Chair" (Armstrong Circle Theatre, 1950), "The Seventh Veil" (Lucky Strike Theatre, 1950), "The Symbol" (Philco-Goodyear Television Playhouse, 1951), "Murder for Laura" (The Web), "In Small Packages (Trapped), and "Jane Eyre" (Kraft Theatre, 1951), among others. Perkins also appeared on television in commercials for Borden's Coffee and General Electric.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The papers provide insight into the personal and professional life of Mardette Perkins, American actress and poet, and consist of correspondence, drafts of writings, clippings, ephemera, computer media, and audiovisual material dating from 1942 to 1996. Perkins' acting career is represented in photographs, clippings, ephemera, and a film of her work for television commercials. The papers contain drafts of Perkins' poetry, including an unpublished manuscript for her "Collected Poems, I," and recordings of her reciting poetry. The papers also shed light on Perkins' experience of psychoanalysis, detailed in her journals from 1961 to 1976.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into five series: I. Correspondence, 1948-1996. II. Writings, 1942-1996. III. Professional Papers, 1945-1966. IV. Personal Papers, 1948-1991. V. Audiovisual Material, 1961-1993.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series contains personal and professional correspondence, dating from 1948 to 1981. Correspondents include Perkins' family members as well as Craig Biddle, a reverend at Perkins' church, with whom she fell in love. In her correspondence with curator Pat Willis at the Beinecke Library Perkins provides information about her life and family history.

did.unittitle: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes correspondence with curator Pat Willis and autobiographical notes describing Mardette Perkins' genealogy, professional career, writing, and personal life.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes notes and other material relating to Jeffrey H. Boyd's book, which Perkins provided feedback on.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Outgoing letter in which Perkins requests a meeting with Straight regarding a part in production of "The Innocence."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes correspondence with husband Robert W. Perkins, brother H. Boyd Edwards and family, Perkins' sons Charlie and Morgan Perkins, their school teachers, and various friends.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes correspondence with friends, family and others, a project proposal for a playwrights' workshop, and letters to the Connecticut State Legislature regarding long term care insurance. Correspondents include: Gabriel J. Biafore, Mary Teresa Boyd, Robert Giaimo, Senator Mark H. Powers, Senator Philip S. Robertson, Ron Smoko, Ricky Weiser, and Frank Yulo.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series contains drafts, a computer disk, and other material pertaining to Perkins' poetry dating from 1942 to 1996.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Not arranged in any particular order.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series contains journals, photographs, printed material, clippings, and personal effects reflecting Perkins' personal life dating from 1948 to 1985. In her journals Perkins details her psychoanalysis with Dr. Altman. The journals are a window into Perkins' experience with anxiety and depression. Evidence of Perkins' affiliations with various universities and churches can be found in this series.

scopecontent.p: The series contains audio recordings, including Perkins reciting her poetry and commercials in which Perkins acted during the 1960s.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains television commercials in which Mardette Perkins appeared circa 1960's. Commercials include: All, Joy, Corn Flakes, Cashmere Liquid, White Cloud, Mrs. Barr, Vicks, Camay, Duncan Hines Cake Mix, Polaroid, apple sauce, and First Penn Bank.
